As state legislatures across the country work to undermine abortion care access, our fight continues.

In August I also joined on to a resolution that expressed support for policies governing access to medication abortion care to be equitable and science-based. 5/6
 
https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-resolution/589/cosponsors?r=2&s=3

Then, while the lawsuit made its way through the courts, my colleagues and I sent a letter to the FDA, calling on the agency to grant permission for certified providers to dispense mifepristone by mail – during the pandemic at the very least. 4/6
 
https://degette.house.gov/sites/degette.house.gov/files/Mifepristone%20Letter%20to%20FDA_6.16.2020.pdf

I was proud to join my colleagues when we filed an amicus brief in the case. 
 
As the COVID-19 public health emergency raged, it was incredibly important for science and medical evidence to guide access to medication abortion and miscarriage care. 3/6
 
https://lee.house.gov/news/press-releases/representative-lee-leads-congressional-democrats-in-filing-amicus-brief-in-acog-v-fda

At the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, in-person dispensing requirements were waived for other medications, but not for one of the pills required for a successful medication abortion called mifepristone. 

@ACOGAction sued the FDA, challenging this in-person requirement. 2/6

Yesterday the @US_FDA took a concrete step that will make medication abortion significantly more accessible – a huge win for equitable reproductive rights.

The U.S. must uphold the right to reproductive health care in our own country and around the globe. People everywhere should have access to safe and legal abortion so they can make informed decisions about their own bodies that allow them to lead full and healthy lives. (4/4)

That’s why I co-sponsored the #AbortionisHealthcareEverywhereAct, which would repeal the Helms Amendment and allow the U.S. to provide comprehensive reproductive health care services and equipment to foreign countries. (3/4)

In effect, this amendment blocks aid to organizations overseas that perform, advocate, or even direct people to abortion care. It denies millions of people the health care they want and need.

On the 48th anniversary of this outdated policy, it's past time to #RepealHelms. (2/4)

For decades, the U.S. has denied abortion care for millions worldwide through the #HelmsAmendment, which was signed into law as part of the Foreign Assistance Act in 1973 and prohibits the use of any U.S. foreign assistance funds for abortion services. (1/4)

That is why I have introduced legislation that would increase access to DXA testing for Medicare beneficiaries and preserve Medicare reimbursement rates for DXA testing.

Advocates believe that hospitals and physician practices acquired by hospitals have decreased the number of DXA tests performed on Medicare beneficiaries because they lose money on the low reimbursement rate.
Medicare covers preventive scans, called DXA, to detect osteoporosis for women, and covers limited DXA scans for men. An important test needed before prescribing medications to treat osteoporosis.

Osteoporosis is responsible for approximately 300,000 hip fracture hospitalizations and almost two million broken bones per year, yet nearly 80 percent of older Americans who suffer bone breaks are not tested or treated for the disease.

Thank you to the @bonehealthBHOF for awarding me with the Congressional Bone Health Champion Award!
 
Bone health has been and will always be a priority of mine.
